bibl.title: Letter from Allen R. Boyd to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 10, 1936

div1.p: Boyd responds to Emilie Lawrence Reed's question concerning wood thrushes.

div1.head: Letter from Allen R. Boyd to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 10, 1936
div1.opener:
KF
LIBRARY OF CONGRESS
OFFICE OF THE EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT
WASHINGTON
July 10, 1936
Dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
So far I haven't been very successful. All
I have found is to the effect that the wood thrush is
“very common about the city parks and gardens, even
about the hedges and shrubbery of the lawn”; and that
they “forage like robins on the lawns”.

The assistant I asked to look into the matter
for me reports that he communicated with one of the
officials of the Agricultural Department who is an orni-
thologist; she referred him to still another ornitholo-
gist who stated that he himself had seen a wood thrush
hopping around his lawn and singing. But neither of them
could cite any book that would give a similar experience.
Perhaps I shall be able to run something more down and shall
let you know if I do.

The thermometer outside my window registers in
the shade 108 degrees. How I wish I were at Blossom Inn!
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Allen R. Boyd Mrs. Walter Reed
Blossom Inn
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
